description:
Acomys dimidiatus, commonly known as the Egyptian spiny mouse, is a small rodent species belonging to the genus Acomys. It is found in North Africa, including Egypt, Libya, and Sudan, as well as parts of the Middle East, such as Israel, Jordan, and Saudi Arabia.

Physically, Acomys dimidiatus is characterized by its distinctive spiny fur, which serves as a defense mechanism against predators. The spines are modified hairs that are stiff and sharp, providing the mouse with a prickly appearance. The body size of the Egyptian spiny mouse typically ranges from 8 to 12 centimeters in length, with a tail length of 7 to 10 centimeters.

Acomys dimidiatus is a nocturnal and arboreal species, spending most of its time foraging for food in the trees and shrubs of its habitat. Its diet consists primarily of seeds, fruits, and insects. The species is known for its adaptability and can thrive in a variety of environments, including deserts, semi-arid regions, and even urban areas.

Reproduction in Acomys dimidiatus is characterized by a relatively short gestation period of around 30 days, and females can give birth to litters of 2 to 5 young. The young are born relatively undeveloped and require parental care for a few weeks before becoming independent.

Overall, the Egyptian spiny mouse is an interesting example of a rodent species that has evolved unique physical adaptations to survive in the challenging environments of North Africa and the Middle East.
